results.title: Ship building with scissors
results.brief_description:
This experimental short film combines theatre, video effects and animation to tell a nautical tale of adventure in the furtherest reaches of the imagination.
Graduate work from RMIT media arts (BA Arts)

results.title: Ship-Busters
results.creator_credit: Great Britain. Royal Air Force. Film Production Unit
results.brief_description: A tribute to the British Dominion Allied Squadrons of the Royal Air Force Coastal Command who took part in the campaign against German-controlled shipping along the coast of Europe during the years 1939-45. The R.A.F. in Norway during WWII.

results.title: Shinto
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Religions of the world”.
Shinto, the indigenous religion of Japan, is one of the world’s oldest religious traditions and currently has around sixty-two million followers. It is rooted in mythology and folk rituals that have been passed down through the generations and although it has no congressional worship, founder, or written doctrine, it has at times served to unify Japan as a nation and to mobilise the country politically. Narrated by Ben Kingsley this video describes the social codes and daily life of its followers.

results.title: Shining conquests
results.creator_credit: Robert Raymond, Christopher McCullough and Opus Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Out of the fiery furnace”.
EPISODE 3 OF OUT OF THE FIERY FURNACE. The flood of wealth from precious metals helps finance the Renaissance, and a great wave of colonization and exploration. In a later century came the “democratic” gold rushes in America and Australia, followed by capital intensive deep-lead mining. The social implications are discussed.

results.title: Shine, Sir!
results.creator_credit: Kiwi Polish Company and The London Press Exchange
results.brief_description: An early advertising film, using animation, which promotes Australian made Kiwi boot and shoe polish and a fair capitalist system that allows for the initiative of youngsters. The ‘Imperial Hotel’ is left short staffed during World War I. Two young boys apply for the position of boot boys, but lament that they can’t clean boots. An Australian soldier, overhearing their conversation, offers each of them a tin of Kiwi boot polish which has impressive results and secures employment for them at the hotel.

results.title: Shine
results.creator_credit: Jane Scott, Scott Hicks and Momentum Films
results.brief_description: The award winning film “Shine” tells the remarkable story of pianist David Helfgott. As a child prodigy he was expected to have a brilliant career, but a nervous breakdown on the brink of international success meant that he was institutionalised and without access to the instrument which he loved so much. His voyage out of that darkness into a life which became filled with love, is truly inspirational. Noah Taylor and Geoffrey Rush give exceptional performances as Helfgott, while Armin Mueller-Stahl who plays David’s father is outstanding. “Shine” was a triumph internationally for both the Australian film industry and the relaunching of Helfgott’s career. It is also a testament to the courage of human beings facing adversity and overcome it. Geoffrey Rush received an Academy Award for his outstanding performance.

results.title: Shinbone Alley
results.creator_credit: Preston M. Fleet, Fine Arts and John Wilson
results.brief_description: Adapted from the “Archy and Mehitabel stories” by Don Marquis with screenplay based on the musical book “Shinbone Alley” by Joe Darion and Mel Brooks, this wonderful animated feature brings with it all the atmosphere and style of its original broadway production, and much more. Its uniqueness is in the ink and paint animation technique blended with a jazzy musical comedy style and an eclectic mix of character personalities including Archy (Eddy Bracken), the philosophic newspaper journalist who after drowning himself comes back as a cockroach reincarnate; Mehitabel (Carol Channing) the sassy, indomitable and occasionally scandalous alley cat and friend of Archy’s; Big Bill (Allen Reed, Sr.) top cat and hell-bent on winning the affections of Mehitabel; and Tyrone T. Tattersall (John Carradine) the charming theatre cat who just loves to ham it up. Whimsical, weird, funny, sometimes dark, but with a fabulous music score by George Kleinsinger supported by the Fine Arts Hollywood Orchestra conducted by George Kleinsinger, the film is more directed at the older child or teenage/adult level. The voice characterisations are simply superb, and the support cast, which includes Hal Smith, Joan Gerber, Ken Sansom, Sel Delano and the Jackie Ward singers as the alley cats, are terrific. Also features Byron Kane as the narrator.

results.title: Shin heike Monogatari = Tales of the Taira
results.creator_credit: Masaichi Nagata, Daiei Motion Picture Company and Kenji Mizoguchi
results.brief_description:
Tales of the Taira Clan’ is set in 1137, a key moment in Japanese history that sees political intrigue among imperial families leading to the transition of power from courtiers and monks to Samurai clans. ‘Tales of the Taira Clan’ is one of only two films by Mizoguchi that were shot in colour. It is also the last of his ‘jidai-geki’ (period films). For this particular film, Mizoguchi asked his art teacher of 40 years before to work as a colour consultant. In ‘Tales of the Taira Clan’, Mizoguchi lives up to his reputation of ‘feminist filmmaker’. This preoccupation with the status of women and their oppression in Japanese society can be traced back to Mizoguchi’s own childhood; following a family reversal of fortune, his 14-year old sister Suzu was put up for adoption and later on sold to a Geisha house. During the Allied occupation of Japan, Mizoguchi was encouraged to make films about women as a contribution to the democratisation of Japanese society. The theme of the self-sacrificing woman who is ultimately destroyed is recurrent is some of Mizoguchi’s best work, including ‘Osaka Elagy’, ‘The Story of the Last Chrysanthemums’, ‘The Life of Oharu’, ‘Sansho the Baillif’ and ‘Ugetsu’. Reference: Gary Morris ‘The World of Kenji Mizoguchi’ Bright Light Film Journal. Online. http://www.brightlightsfilms.com/22/mizoguchi.html. Also available on VHS.

Credits: Producer, Masachi Nagata ; director, Kenji Mizoguchi ; writers, Yoshikata Yoda, Masahige Narusawa, Kyuichi Tsuji ; photography, Kazuo Miyagaw ; music, Fumio Hayasak, Masaru Sato.
Cast: Raizo Ichikawa, Ichijiro Oya, Yoshiko Kuga, Tatsuya Ishiguro, Michiyo Kogure, Eijiro Yanagi.

results.title: Shimmer in the city (A)
results.creator_credit: Special Broadcasting Service Corporation and Amanda Hickey
results.brief_description: A detailed look at urban Aboriginal art through interviews with artists, national and international curators, art dealers and art critics, and their views on the place of the work in relation to traditional Aboriginal art as well as Australian society at large. The notion of preconceived ideas of Aboriginal art is discussed as well as the non-stereotypical aboriginality represented in the urban artist’s work where mythical, cultural and environmental heritage is referred to, but situated politically as a confrontation of past and present issues effecting indigenous Australians. Through the interviews with the artists and critics of their work the autobiographical nature of the art is evoked, underlining both the personal and broad social relevance of the art to contemporary Aboriginal experience. It is thorough documentary on the broad spectrum of work being produced that also raises the key issues of Aboriginal ownership of imagery and the question of Aboriginal copyright.

results.title: Shiloh 2: Shiloh Season
results.creator_credit: Utopia Pictures, Carl Borack, Dale Rosenbloom and Sandy Tung
results.brief_description: Marty Preston (Zachary Browne) is a well-meaning 12-year-old who adopts Shiloh, a beagle who was treated cruelly by his first master, a bitter alcoholic named Judd (Scott Wilson). However, when Judd is hurt in a car accident, Marty realises Judd may have lost one of the only friends he ever had, even if he did mistreat Shiloh. With help from his parents Marty tries to get Judd back on his feet both physically and emotionally, and learns a lot of hard lessons about growing up in the process.
